summary: This is a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys to Judge Alison J. Nathan, outlining 12 pretrial motions they intend to file in her criminal case. The motions challenge the indictment on various grounds including breach of a non-prosecution agreement, statute of limitations, due process violations, and multiplicity of charges. The letter also discusses procedures for filing redacted motions containing confidential discovery information.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The client of the law firm Cohen & Gresser LLP, who is the subject of the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The letter outlines multiple defense motions filed on her behalf.

persons.name: Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: The judge presiding over the criminal case United States v. Ghislaine Maxwell. The letter is addressed to her to inform her of the upcoming pretrial motions.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP representing Ghislaine Maxwell. He is a signatory on the letter outlining the pretrial motions.

persons.name: Christian R. Everdell
persons.context: Attorney from Cohen & Gresser LLP representing Ghislaine Maxwell. He is listed as a co-signatory on the letter.

connections.description: Mark S. Cohen is listed as a defense attorney filing pretrial motions on behalf of his client, Ghislaine Maxwell.
Christian R. Everdell is listed as a defense attorney filing pretrial motions on behalf of his client, Ghislaine Maxwell.
Both are attorneys at Cohen & Gresser LLP and are jointly representing Ghislaine Maxwell, as evidenced by their co-signature on the court filing.
Judge Nathan is the presiding judge over the criminal case against Ghislaine Maxwell.

events.title: Filing of Pretrial Motion Notice
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorneys notify the court of their intent to file 12 pretrial motions challenging the superseding indictment.

locations: 40 Foley Square, New York, New York 10007
800 Third Avenue, 21st Floor, New York, New York 10022
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense team planned to file 12 separate pretrial motions challenging the superseding indictment against her.
One key motion sought to dismiss the indictment based on an alleged breach of a Non-Prosecution Agreement, suggesting the existence of a prior immunity deal.
Multiple motions challenged counts as time-barred, indicating a statute of limitations defense strategy.
The defense indicated several motions would contain redactions due to confidential discovery information, requiring sealed and public versions.
